{alonbk2@gmail.com, noam.levi@epfl.ch, ybarsinai@gmail.com}
Abstract

We study the generalization properties of binary logistic classification in a simplified setting, for which a "memorizing" and "generalizing" solution can always be strictly defined, and elucidate empirically and analytically the mechanism underlying Grokking in its dynamics. We analyze the asymptotic long-time dynamics of logistic classification on a random feature model with a constant label and show that it exhibits Grokking, in the sense of delayed generalization and non-monotonic test loss. We find that Grokking is amplified when classification is applied to training sets which are on the verge of linear separability. Even though a perfect generalizing solution always exists, we prove the implicit bias of the logisitc loss will cause the model to overfit if the training data is linearly separable from the origin. For training sets that are not separable from the origin, the model will always generalize perfectly asymptotically, but overfitting may occur at early stages of training. Importantly, in the vicinity of the transition, that is, for training sets that are almost separable from the origin, the model may overfit for arbitrarily long times before generalizing. We gain more insights by examining a tractable one-dimensional toy model that quantitatively captures the key features of the full model. Finally, we highlight intriguing common properties of our findings with recent literature, suggesting that grokking generally occurs in proximity to the interpolation threshold, reminiscent of critical phenomena often observed in physical systems.

1 Introduction

Understanding the relationship between the intrinsic properties of data, the training dynamics of neural networks (NNs), and their ability to generalize is crucial to explaining the success of modern machine learning (ML) algorithms. In particular, highly over-parameterized models based on the transformer architecture (Vaswani et al., 2023), such as Large Language Models (LLMs) (OpenAI, 2023; Google, 2023; Zeng et al., 2022; Brown et al., 2020; Chowdhery et al., 2022; Anil et al., 2023), as well as state of the art models for computer vision (Srivastava and Sharma, 2023), defy expectations and are able to generalize with a number of parameters far exceeding the so called interpolation threshold (Kaplan et al., 2020; Schaeffer et al., 2023). Interestingly, these models have been shown to exhibit unpredictable behaviors when changing the number of network parameters, not only with respect to generalization, but also in their learning dynamics.

One such phenomenon is Grokking, first observed by (Power et al., 2022) when training a transformer model on modular arithmetic tasks. Grokking occurs when a model initially achieves perfect training accuracy but no generalization (i.e. no better than a random predictor), and upon further training, transitions to almost perfect generalization. This phenomenon has garnered substantial attention in recent years (Gromov, 2023; Liu et al., 2023; Xu et al., 2023) due to its striking contrast with naive expectations, whereby over-fitting is generally seen as an undesirable property of models that should not generalize with further training, originally dealt with using early stopping (Prechelt, 1996).

In this work, we study grokking in a synthetic, yet illuminating, setting where the asymptotic optimal solution can always be identified, allowing a sharp definition of notions which are typically ambiguous, such as ‚Äúmemorization‚Äù and ‚Äúlearning‚Äù. Concretely, we focus on the extreme case of feature noise where the network needs to ignore the input features and classify all points as a constant label. The input data are NùëÅNitalic_N points in ‚Ñùdsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, drawn independently from an isotropic normal distribution with diagonal covariance, ùíôi‚àºùí©‚Å¢(0,œÉ‚Å¢ùë∞d)similar-tosubscriptùíôùëñùí©0ùúésubscriptùë∞ùëë\bm{x}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma\bm{I}_{d})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_œÉ bold_italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where ùë∞dsubscriptùë∞ùëë\bm{I}_{d}bold_italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the d√ódùëëùëëd\times ditalic_d √ó italic_d identity matrix and œÉ>0ùúé0\sigma>0italic_œÉ > 0. We study the limit of large N,d‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅùëëN,d\to\inftyitalic_N , italic_d ‚Üí ‚àû, while keeping the ratio Œª=d/NùúÜùëëùëÅ\lambda=d/Nitalic_Œª = italic_d / italic_N fixed. Our main contributions are:

  • ‚Ä¢

    We demonstrate both numerically and analytically that grokking may occur in this setting, and is promoted when ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª is close to 1/2 and œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ is large.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We demonstrate that this occurs because Œª=1/2ùúÜ12\lambda=1/2italic_Œª = 1 / 2 is the effective interpolation threshold, in the sense that for Œª<1/2ùúÜ12\lambda<1/2italic_Œª < 1 / 2 the model will almost surely asymptotically approach perfect generalization accuracy and vanishing loss. For Œª>1/2ùúÜ12\lambda>1/2italic_Œª > 1 / 2 the model will almost surely achieve imperfect generalization accuracy and the population loss will diverge at long times.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We prove that the generalization properties depend only on whether the training set is linearly separable from the origin. The model will achieve asymptotically optimal generalization if and only if the origin is contained in the convex hull of the training set.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Moreover, we show that near the threshold value, the dynamics may generically track the overfitting solution for arbitrarily long times before transitioning to the optimal generalizing solution, manifesting as non-monotonicity of the test loss and delayed generalization.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We construct a simple, one-dimensional model which captures the salient aspects of the problem, and explicitly solve the time evolution of the network parameters for several interesting cases.

The main takeaway from our setup is that grokking happens near critical points in long-term dynamics, similar to the phenomenon known in the physics literature as ‚Äôcritical slowing down‚Äô. While further study is needed, we believe this applies to other grokking examples (see for example (Levi et al., 2023; Liu et al., 2023; Gromov, 2023)).

2 Related Work

Following the discovery of grokking by Power et al. (2022), numerous studies have attempted to elucidate its underlying mechanisms. Liu et al. (2022) showed that when sufficient data determines the structured representation, perfect generalization can be achieved on a non-modular addition task. Other works have identified factors contributing to grokking (Davies et al., 2023; Nanda et al., 2023), analyzed the trigonometric algorithms learned by networks after grokking (Nanda et al., 2023; Chughtai et al., 2023; Merrill et al., 2023; Gromov, 2023), and demonstrated similar dynamics in sparse parity tasks (Merrill et al., 2023). Additional works proposed "slingshots" (Thilak et al., 2022) or "oscillations" (Notsawo et al., 2023) as explanations for grokking, while others have studied the role of regularization, which has proven to significantly impact grokking in certain scenarios (Power et al., 2022; Liu et al., 2023). Our work requires none of these in order to exhibit or explain grokking.

Recently, a body of works on solvable models which grok in various settings has emerged. Liu et al. (2023); Kumar et al. (2023) and Lyu et al. (2024) have linked grokking to memorization and transitions from lazy to rich dynamics. ≈Ωunkoviƒç and Ilievski (2022); Gromov (2023); Doshi et al. (2024) analyzed solvable models exhibiting grokking and related their findings to the formation of latent-space structure, Xu et al. (2023) related grokking to benign over-fitting for ReLU networks on XOR data, Rubin et al. (2024) described grokking as a first-order phase transition, and Levi et al. (2023) provide the full dynamical solution of grokking in linear regression. Our work attempts to fill the gap between solvable models and representation learning, whereby we can always identify the optimal solutions, while still solving the dynamics of the model. To accomplish this, our work relies heavily on the results of Soudry et al. (2018); Nacson et al. (2019); Ji and Telgarsky (2019), which analyze the late-time dynamics properties of logistic regression for separable and inseparable data under gradient descent (GD).

3 Grokking in Binary Classification

3.1 Model Setup and Empirical Results

We will now define the setup of the model performing binary classification using logistic regression and present the numerical evidence for grokking. 3.2 The Mechanism of Grokking in the Current Setting

We begin by examining the optimal generalizing solution, that indicates the network has properly learned the task. Since the support of the input distribution is unbounded, the network should put all points in ‚Ñùdsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on the same side of the separating hyperplane, or in other words, push the decision boundary to infinity.

These results are closely related to the framework developed by (Soudry et al., 2018), who studied the convergence of binary classification for linearly separable data, and later expanded by (Ji and Telgarsky, 2019) for inseparable data. In our case, since the model contains a bias term and all labels are the same, the data is always separable by a hyperplane ‚Äúat infinity‚Äù. To use their framework, we need to work in an extended space of dimension d+1ùëë1d+1italic_d + 1, where we define the extended weight vector ùíò=(ùë∫,b)‚àà‚Ñùd+1ùíòùë∫ùëèsuperscript‚Ñùùëë1\bm{w}=(\bm{S},b)\in\mathbb{R}^{d+1}bold_italic_w = ( bold_italic_S , italic_b ) ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A direct corollary of Theorem 3 from (Soudry et al., 2018) is that at long times, the training dynamics behave as

Connecting this result to the previous discussion, we see indeed that either |b|ùëè|b|| italic_b | and/or ‚à•ùë∫‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•ùë∫\left\lVert{\bm{S}}\right\rVert‚à• bold_italic_S ‚à• must diverge at long times, and the question is now reduced to what is the direction of ùíòSVMsubscriptùíòSVM\bm{w}_{\mathrm{SVM}}bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_SVM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The true generalizing solution, which classifies correctly all points in ‚Ñùdsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is when ùíòSVM=(0,‚àí1)subscriptùíòSVM01{\bm{w}_{\mathrm{SVM}}}=(0,-1)bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_SVM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 0 , - 1 ), i.e. when it points in the direction of the bias and the separating plane is at infinity. This is exactly the aforementioned condition b‚Üí‚àí‚àû‚Üíùëèb\to-\inftyitalic_b ‚Üí - ‚àû and |b|/‚à•ùë∫‚à•‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëèdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùë∫|b|/\left\lVert{\bm{S}}\right\rVert\to\infty| italic_b | / ‚à• bold_italic_S ‚à• ‚Üí ‚àû. Overfitting occurs when the hyperplane is only far enough from the data to correctly classify all the training samples. In the extended space, this means that ùíòSVMsubscriptùíòSVM{\bm{w}_{\mathrm{SVM}}}bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_SVM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT also contains a component in the direction of the data, and the model did not learn correctly the data distribution.

We are now ready to sketch our main claims regarding the grokking phenomenology presented in Fig. 1. The details will be fleshed out in the next subsections. We claim that:

  • ‚Ä¢

    The generalization and overfitting at long times depend only on whether the training samples (in ‚Ñùdsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) are linearly separable from the origin. We call a training set separable if there exists a vector ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S such that ‚àÄi‚Å¢ùë∫T‚Å¢ùíôi<‚àí1for-allùëñsuperscriptùë∫ùëásubscriptùíôùëñ1\forall i\ \bm{S}^{T}\bm{x}_{i}<-1‚àÄ italic_i bold_italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < - 1, and inseparable otherwise.

  • ‚Ä¢

    In the limit of large N,dùëÅùëëN,ditalic_N , italic_d, the training set is almost surely separable (inseparable) for Œª>12ùúÜ12\lambda>\frac{1}{2}italic_Œª > divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG (Œª<12ùúÜ12\lambda<\frac{1}{2}italic_Œª < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG). This a direct corollary of Wendel‚Äôs theorem, (Wendel, 1962), see App. A for additional details.

  • ‚Ä¢

    For separable training sets (Œª>12ùúÜ12\lambda>\frac{1}{2}italic_Œª > divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG), the model will always overfit, and the limiting generalization accuracy is directly related to the optimal separating margin. For inseparable training sets (Œª<12ùúÜ12\lambda<\frac{1}{2}italic_Œª < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG) the model will always generalize perfectly: bùëèbitalic_b diverges at long times and ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S saturates on a finite value limt‚Üí‚àûùë∫‚Å¢(t)=ùë∫‚àûsubscript‚Üíùë°ùë∫ùë°subscriptùë∫\lim_{t\to\infty}\bm{S}(t)=\bm{S}_{\infty}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_S ( italic_t ) = bold_italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is shown in Sec. 3.3.

  • ‚Ä¢

    However, for Œª‚â≤12less-than-or-similar-toùúÜ12\lambda\lesssim\frac{1}{2}italic_Œª ‚â≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG, the training set is on the verge of separability, and ‚à•ùë∫‚àû‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë∫\left\lVert{\bm{S}_{\infty}}\right\rVert‚à• bold_italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• may be arbitrarily large. Consequently, dynamics may take arbitrarily long times to reach the generalizing solution. This is the underlying mechanism of grokking in this setting.

3.3 Overfitting and Linear Separability

When will over-fitting occur? Due to the ‚Äúexponential tail‚Äù of the cross-entropy loss, at late times the loss is dominated by samples with large network outputs f=ùë∫T‚Å¢ùíô+bùëìsuperscriptùë∫ùëáùíôùëèf=\bm{S}^{T}\bm{x}+bitalic_f = bold_italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x + italic_b, for which the cross-entropy loss ‚Ñì‚Å¢(f)‚Ñìùëì\ell(f)roman_‚Ñì ( italic_f ) of Eq. 1, approaches the exponential loss ‚Ñìe‚Å¢(f)=efsubscript‚Ñìùëíùëìsuperscriptùëíùëì\ell_{e}(f)=e^{f}roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ) = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (Soudry et al., 2018; Nacson et al., 2019). Specifically, the exponential loss will converge to the same late time dynamics as the cross entropy loss. Therefore, we will consider the exponential loss for which the calculations are tractable,

‚Ñíe‚Å¢(ùë∫,b)=1N‚Å¢‚àëi=1Neùë∫T‚Å¢ùíôi+b.subscript‚Ñíùëíùë∫ùëè1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptùëísuperscriptùë∫ùëásubscriptùíôùëñùëè\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{e}(\bm{S},b)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}e^{\bm{S}^{T}% \bm{x}_{i}+b}.caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_S , italic_b ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (8)

In the gradient-flow limit, the dynamics for the exponential loss are

3.4 When Will We See Grokking?

We have established that for inseparable sets ùë∫‚Å¢(t)ùë∫ùë°\bm{S}(t)bold_italic_S ( italic_t ) flows to a fixed point ùë∫‚àûsubscriptùë∫\bm{S}_{\infty}bold_italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT while for separable sets it diverges at long times. This drastic change in the asymptotic value is responsible for grokking, much like in (Rubin et al., 2024) and (Levi et al., 2023), who showed that grokking occurs near a phase transition.

The manifestation of this discontinuity in our setting is that ‚à•ùë∫‚àû‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë∫\left\lVert{\bm{S}_{\infty}}\right\rVert‚à• bold_italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• diverges when the training set is almost separable. This statement is formally proven in App. D and empirically demonstrated in Fig. 1. It can also be obtained as a corollary of (Ji and Telgarsky, 2019).

To see this intuitively, consider a training set which is only slightly inseparable from the origin, i.e. one can make it separable by translating all points by a small amount. Since the set is inseparable, we asymptotically have ùë∫‚Å¢(t)‚Üíùë∫‚àû‚Üíùë∫ùë°subscriptùë∫\bm{S}(t)\to\bm{S}_{\infty}bold_italic_S ( italic_t ) ‚Üí bold_italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, on the translated points, ‚à•ùë∫‚Å¢(t)‚à•‚Üí‚àû‚Üídelimited-‚à•‚à•ùë∫ùë°\left\lVert{\bm{S}(t)}\right\rVert\to\infty‚à• bold_italic_S ( italic_t ) ‚à• ‚Üí ‚àû. Since the solution to the gradient flow equations is smooth in the position of the training points, we must have that ‚à•ùë∫‚àû‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë∫\left\lVert{\bm{S}_{\infty}}\right\rVert‚à• bold_italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• is large.

Grokking occurs when the dynamics first follow the path towards ùë∫‚àûsubscriptùë∫\bm{S}_{\infty}bold_italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is large but finite, while bùëèbitalic_b remains small, and only then transition into the generalizing solution b‚Üí‚àí‚àû‚Üíùëèb\to-\inftyitalic_b ‚Üí - ‚àû. In this case we will see small values of |b|/‚à•ùë∫‚Å¢(t)‚à•ùëèdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùë∫ùë°|b|/\left\lVert{\bm{S}(t)}\right\rVert| italic_b | / ‚à• bold_italic_S ( italic_t ) ‚à• at intermediate times and therefore delayed generalization. However, the dynamics may also flow along a different path in which ùë∫‚Å¢(t)ùë∫ùë°\bm{S}(t)bold_italic_S ( italic_t ) and b‚Å¢(t)ùëèùë°b(t)italic_b ( italic_t ) grow at a comparable rate. Here, we show that grokking occurs generically when œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ is large enough.

To see this, it useful to define the rescaled variables ùíôi~=ùíôi/œÉ~subscriptùíôùëñsubscriptùíôùëñùúé\tilde{\bm{x}_{i}}=\bm{x}_{i}/\sigmaover~ start_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_œÉ, ùë∫~=œÉ‚Å¢ùë∫~ùë∫ùúéùë∫\tilde{\bm{S}}=\sigma\bm{S}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_S end_ARG = italic_œÉ bold_italic_S. Clearly, ùíô~i‚àºùí©‚Å¢(0,ùë∞ùíÖ)similar-tosubscript~ùíôùëñùí©0subscriptùë∞ùíÖ\tilde{\bm{x}}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\bm{I_{d}})over~ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_N ( 0 , bold_italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The gradient flow equations in terms of the rescaled variables are (we study the exponential loss here for simplicity)

Note that these are identical to the gradient flow equations of the original variables, Eq. 9 but the dynamics of ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S are faster by factor of œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, for large œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ and large ùë∫‚àûsubscriptùë∫\bm{S}_{\infty}bold_italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we expect to see delayed generalization. The ‚ÄúGrokking time‚Äù, i.e. the difference between the times for which training and generalization accuracy surpass a threshold, can truly diverge only if both Œª‚Üí0.5‚ÜíùúÜ0.5\lambda\rightarrow 0.5italic_Œª ‚Üí 0.5 and œÉ‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùúé\sigma\rightarrow\inftyitalic_œÉ ‚Üí ‚àû. This is also demonstrated for the simplified model (discussed below), see the right-most panel of Fig. 3.

Interestingly, using adaptive momentum based optimizers like ADAM  (Kingma and Ba, 2017), one can see grokking even for œÉ=1ùúé1\sigma=1italic_œÉ = 1: Since these optimizers use a different learning rate for each parameter, based on historical gradients, this can lead to faster convergence in the direction of ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S, enabling grokking for a similar reason as increasing œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ. For elaboration, and discussion of the (similar) effect of initial conditions, see App. F.

4 Insights From a Simplified Model

Our main claim is that the asymptotic dynamics depend only on the separability of the training set, and that grokking occurs at the edge of linear separability. This intuition works also at low dimensions, which are easier to understand.

Consider the case of d=1ùëë1d=1italic_d = 1. In this case, separability boils down to asking whether the origin is contained between the extremal points min‚Å°{xi}subscriptùë•ùëñ\min\{x_{i}\}roman_min { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and max‚Å°{xi}subscriptùë•ùëñ\max\{x_{i}\}roman_max { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Therefore, all the phenomenology of the full model described in the previous sections can be captured by a training set consisting of only 2 points x1,x2subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2x_{1},x_{2}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For consistency with the problem of Gaussian data, we parameterize this set as

4.1 Grokking Time and Universality

We begin by noting that the analytical result of b‚Å¢(t)ùëèùë°b(t)italic_b ( italic_t ) for Œª=0.5ùúÜ0.5\lambda=0.5italic_Œª = 0.5 can describe quite well the results of the full model, see middle panel of Fig. 1. This fact, combined with the assumption that the divergence of S‚àûsubscriptùëÜS_{\infty}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the full model is also logarithmic (as was verified numerically), the behavior of the Grokking time (defined below) is expected to be the same in both models. We will now calculate it in the simplified model.

which is verified numerically in Fig. 4. Further details can be found in Sec. E.3.

We note that this result bears a striking resemblance to that of (Levi et al., 2023), which employed the MSE loss in a linear regression problem, again for NùëÅNitalic_N points sampled iid from an isotropic Gaussian distribution. In their setting, the interpolation threshold is at Œª=1ùúÜ1\lambda=1italic_Œª = 1, in the sense that for Œª<1ùúÜ1\lambda<1italic_Œª < 1 the model always generalizes asymptotically, and never generalizes for Œª>1ùúÜ1\lambda>1italic_Œª > 1. They also found that the grokking time diverges logarithmically as a function of the distance from criticality, (tgen‚àó‚àíttr‚àó)/ttr‚àó‚àù|log‚Å°(1‚àíŒª)|proportional-tosuperscriptsubscriptùë°gensuperscriptsubscriptùë°trsuperscriptsubscriptùë°tr1ùúÜ{(t_{\mathrm{gen}}^{*}-t_{\mathrm{tr}}^{*})}/{t_{\mathrm{tr}}^{*}}\propto|\log% {(1-\sqrt{\lambda})}|( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_gen end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_tr end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) / italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_tr end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àù | roman_log ( 1 - square-root start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG ) |, which was explained in terms of a ‚Äúcritical slowing down‚Äù effect, arising from a vanishing eigenvalue of the data covariance near criticality. While the two problems are quite different, they both display a critical behavior near an effective interpolation threshold of the corresponding problem. We believe this is not a coincidence but rather a manifestation of a deeper relation between divergent behaviors in NNs and the intrinsic structure of the training data. We explore the various aspects of these universal properties in future work.

5 Conclusions and Limitations

In this work, we attempted to fill a gap in the Grokking literature, by sharply defining and tracking both empirically and analytically the "memorizing" and "generalizing" solutions in an interesting setting. We achieved this by constructing a simple yet informative example of "noise" classification, where the optimal solutions can always be found analytically.

Our work can be divided into two parts. First, we studied empirically the dynamics of "noise" classification, and demonstrated that grokking is clearly exhibited when the classifier transitions from the "memorizing" solution to the "generalizing" one. Additionally, we show that this grokking transition strongly depends on the underlying properties of the data, as it only occurs when the data is on the verge of being linearly separable from the origin in dùëëditalic_d dimensions, given by ŒªcsubscriptùúÜùëê\lambda_{c}italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In the second part we presented a simple, one dimensional effective description of the full problem, and showed that it captures the salient properties leading to grokking. Employing this simple model, we are able to show that the grokking time diverges as the data becomes closer to linearly separable in dùëëditalic_d dimensions, and provide analytical predictions for the grokking time as a function of the properties of the data alone.

Finally, the existence of ŒªcsubscriptùúÜùëê\lambda_{c}italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which can be identified as the effective interpolation threshold for this problem, is a strong hint at the connection between grokking, and other emergent phenomena in deep learning, such as double descent. We will further address this connection in future work.

Limitations:  We considered a specific problem of classifying irrelevant features, under a particular choice of feature distribution, namely, Normal with zero mean in high dimensions. It is natural to ask how our results extend to more complex data, for instance including non-trivial correlations, hierarchical structure, or even a finite distribution (for instance (Gromov, 2023)). While we believe the same analysis can be repeated in these instances, in the sense of (non)linear separability, we leave this to future work.

All of the analytics were done in the GF limit, and while our results were verified by experiments with finite learning rate, it may be interesting to study how large learning rates effect this setup, possibly relating to catapults (Lewkowycz et al., 2020) or the edge of stability literature (Cohen et al., 2022).

Lastly, we did not study the prospect of nonlinear logistic regression, which is closer to deep learning models in the wild. We believe some of our results may be generalized, provided we accept a ‚Äúfeature map‚Äù description of the network up to the last layer, and consider the SVM solution on the learned features.

Appendix A Separability and Wendel‚Äôs Theorem

Wendel‚Äôs theorem [Wendel, 1962] states that the probability that NùëÅNitalic_N random vectors drawn from an isotropic distribution in dùëëditalic_d dimensions is

This is a the cumulative probability function of the Binomial distribution, i.e. the probability that the the number of successes is greater than dùëëditalic_d out of N‚àí1ùëÅ1N-1italic_N - 1 attempts with success probability 1212\frac{1}{2}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG. The central limit theorem states that in the limit of large N,dùëÅùëëN,ditalic_N , italic_d the binomial distribution approaches a Gaussian, and thus the cumulative distribution function approaches the error function. Straightforward algebra gives that for large N,dùëÅùëëN,ditalic_N , italic_d we have

Appendix B Relation to canonical examples

In this section, we will discuss the similarities and differences of our work with previous examples of Grokking in the literature, focusing on the seminal work of Power et. al. [Power et al., 2022]. We first note that Grokking at Power et. al. is significant when the fraction of the data used for training Œ±=Nt‚Å¢r‚Å¢a‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚Å¢g/NùõºsubscriptùëÅùë°ùëüùëéùëñùëõùëñùëõùëîùëÅ\alpha=N_{training}/Nitalic_Œ± = italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n italic_i italic_n italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_N is near a critical value Œ±csubscriptùõºùëê\alpha_{c}italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, in the sense that the system achieves perfect generalization if and only if Œ±>Œ±cùõºsubscriptùõºùëê\alpha>\alpha_{c}italic_Œ± > italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as can be seen in Fig. 1 (center) of their paper. We expect that this non-analytic behavior in the long time limit of training will be the crucial property that underlies grokking. That is, we expect that near such points the dynamics will be slow. We note that Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± in Power et. al. is analogous to our ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª parameter, defining an effective "interpolation threshold" for the modular arithmetic problem.

Secondly, we note that a noticeable difference between our work and that of Power et. al. is that in our case, the accuracy shows a rise from the start rather than staying at chance level for a long time before generalizing. We argue that this is only a superficial discrepancy that depends on the choice of optimizer and fine-tuning of hyperparameters, and that the fundamental mechanism (that grokking occurs near critical points in which solutions exchange stability and dynamics are generically slow) is the same.

Indeed, in Fig. 5 we show that our setup is capable of grokking with accuracy staying at chance level (50%) at the start, similar to Power et al. We achieved this by using ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª values closer to half (‚Äúalmost separable‚Äù) and the Adam optimizer instead of vanilla gradient descent (GD). The fact that this optimizer converges faster on the training data is no coincidence: the adaptive learning rate leads to quicker convergence to large values of |S|ùëÜ|S|| italic_S | (the ‚Äúmemorizing solution"), maintaining accuracy at chance level until later stages, before going to large ‚àíbùëè-b- italic_b (the "generalizing solution"). Notably, Power et al. also used Adam (or AdamW). In conclusion, although Adam can lead to a slightly "cleaner" grokking result, we explored GD because it is easier to derive analytical insights from it while, we believe, not changing the underlying mechanism of grokking. Finally, We will also note that the non-monotonicity of the test loss is also a typical sign of Grokking that can be seen in our setup (for example, compare Fig. 4 of Power et al. with the test loss in Fig. 5).

Appendix D Proof that S‚àûsubscriptùëÜS_{\infty}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT diverges for almost separable data

We look at the function

We will assume n>dùëõùëën>ditalic_n > italic_d and that the data is in general position, and that it is not separable from the origin. Since for every SùëÜSitalic_S we must have S‚ãÖxi>0‚ãÖùëÜsubscriptùë•ùëñ0S\cdot x_{i}>0italic_S ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 for some iùëñiitalic_i, it is easy to see that fùëìfitalic_f diverges when SùëÜSitalic_S grows large in any direction. Since f>0ùëì0f>0italic_f > 0, there exists a global minimum at finite SùëÜSitalic_S.

A minimum (which is also unique under our assumptions but that‚Äôs not crucial) obeys

‚àÇf‚àÇS=‚àëi=1nxi‚Å¢eS‚ãÖxi=0ùëìùëÜsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptùëí‚ãÖùëÜsubscriptùë•ùëñ0\displaystyle\frac{\partial f}{\partial S}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}e^{S\cdot x_{i}}=0divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_f end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_S end_ARG = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 (25)

If we divide this expression by fùëìfitalic_f, we get

‚àëi=1npi‚Å¢xisuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}x_{i}‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =0absent0\displaystyle=0= 0 pisubscriptùëùùëñ\displaystyle p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =eS‚ãÖxifabsentsuperscriptùëí‚ãÖùëÜsubscriptùë•ùëñùëì\displaystyle=\frac{e^{S\cdot x_{i}}}{f}= divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_f end_ARG 0‚â§pi‚â§1,‚àëipi=1formulae-sequence0subscriptùëùùëñ1subscriptùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1\displaystyle 0\leq p_{i}\leq 1,\quad\sum_{i}p_{i}=10 ‚â§ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ 1 , ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 (26)

Eq. 26 means that the origin is a convex combination of the sample points with weights pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We found that a necessary condition for the existence of a critical point at a finite SùëÜSitalic_S is that the origin is contained in the convex hull of the sample points. This is of course equivalent to the condition that the origin is not linearly separable from the sample data.

We want to show that if the data is almost separable, that is, if it is not separable but the origin is close to the boundary of the convex hull, then SùëÜSitalic_S must be large. The intuition for this comes from Eq. 26: if the origin is very close to the boundary of the convex hull then some of the pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT‚Äôs must be very large compared to the others, which can only happen if SùëÜSitalic_S is large.

In fact, the origin is exactly on the boundary of the convex hull (that is, the data is exactly on the edge of separability) if and only if for every representation of the origin as a convex combination of the sample points,

‚àëi=1nqi‚Å¢xi=0,superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëûùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ0\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}q_{i}x_{i}=0\ ,‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 , (27)

the weights qisubscriptùëûùëñq_{i}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are non zero only for kùëòkitalic_k sample points, say xi,‚Ä¶,xksubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëòx_{i},\dots,x_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with k‚â§dùëòùëëk\leq ditalic_k ‚â§ italic_d, and x1,‚Ä¶‚Å¢xksubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëòx_{1},\dots x_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the vertices of a facet of the convex hull. This naturally leads to the definition:

Definition

We say that the origin is œµitalic-œµ\epsilonitalic_œµ-close to the boundary if there exist kùëòkitalic_k points x1,‚Ä¶,xksubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëòx_{1},\dots,x_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that for every representation of the type of Eq. 27, the total weight assigned to x1,‚Ä¶‚Å¢xksubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëòx_{1},\dots x_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is at least 1‚àíœµ1italic-œµ1-\epsilon1 - italic_œµ,

Appendix E Details of the Simplified Model

E.1 Justification and Relation to the Full Model

We will provide here supplemental results regarding the justification of the simplified model (by numerical comparison to the full model). To obtain the results we average over different random realizations: Assuming the so-called ‚Äúself averaging‚Äù property, we know that the average over a large number of finite systems should give us the same result as the infinite system (where N,d‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅùëëN,d\rightarrow\inftyitalic_N , italic_d ‚Üí ‚àû and the ratio is constant).

In the non-separable case, ùë∫‚àûsubscriptùë∫\bm{S}_{\infty}bold_italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be found by any optimizer that minimizes the loss ‚Ñí=‚àëeùë∫T‚Å¢ùíôùíä‚Ñísuperscriptùëísuperscriptùë∫ùëásubscriptùíôùíä\mathcal{L}=\sum e^{\bm{S}^{T}\bm{x_{i}}}caligraphic_L = ‚àë italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We note that when getting close to the transition point, for any finite-sized system we have some probability of getting a separable set (even though Œª<0.5ùúÜ0.5\lambda<0.5italic_Œª < 0.5), see Eq. 19. In this case, we just ignore the the result: In the right panel of Fig. 6 we present the fraction of realizations that are separable. This will probably introduce some bias into the results which is likely the cause of the fact that the average of positive samples (and similarly, the margin) does not go exactly to zero for Œª‚Üí0.5‚ÜíùúÜ0.5\lambda\rightarrow 0.5italic_Œª ‚Üí 0.5 (see Fig. 7). In the left panel of Fig. 6 we present the fraction of positive ùë∫‚àûT‚à•ùë∫‚àû‚à•‚Å¢ùíôisubscriptsuperscriptùë∫ùëádelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë∫subscriptùíôùëñ{\frac{\bm{S}^{T}_{\infty}}{\left\lVert{\bm{S}_{\infty}}\right\rVert}\bm{x}_{i}}divide start_ARG bold_italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . While there exist analytical solutions for Eq. 32, they do not necessarily provide any intuition, and so we find it better to begin by investigating three special representative cases:

  1. 1.

F.2 Optimizer

The effect of changing the optimizer to Adam is demonstrated in Fig. 10. We note that the fact that adaptive-type optimizers change each learning rate individually based on past gradients, leads the dynamics faster in the direction of ‚à•ùë∫‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•ùë∫\left\lVert{\bm{S}}\right\rVert‚à• bold_italic_S ‚à•, relatively to bùëèbitalic_b. The fact that it makes ‚à•ùë∫‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•ùë∫\left\lVert{\bm{S}}\right\rVert‚à• bold_italic_S ‚à• change faster (and not slower) than bùëèbitalic_b, is probably related to the fact that ùë∫ùë∫\bm{S}bold_italic_S is a vector in high dimension: Moving each component of such vector will result in a change of the norm in a rate that is proportional to dùëë\sqrt{d}square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG, but this may need further investigation. We will also note that using a different optimizer for the non-separable region where, will lead to a different solution than the hard margin SVM, as is also discussed by Soudry et al. [Soudry et al., 2018]. This means that the results we developed in the main text will not hold, but we can still expect to obtain accuracy smaller than one since ‚à•ùë∫‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•ùë∫\left\lVert{\bm{S}}\right\rVert‚à• bold_italic_S ‚à• diverges, as indeed can be seen in Fig. 10.

F.4 Different loss

Appendix H Supplemental Details of Experiments

In this section, we will provide information regarding the experiments. All of our results are computed in Python, using the standard gradient-decent of the PyTorch library.

We begin by noting that the results of the left panels of Fig. 1 (and all of the results in Section F) can be easily obtained even on a personal laptop. We had only three "large" experiments, which are presented in the right-most column of Fig. 1 (and in Fig. 7):

(1) Calculation of ‚à•ùë∫‚àû‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë∫\left\lVert{\bm{S}_{\infty}}\right\rVert‚à• bold_italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• and ùë∫T‚Å¢xisuperscriptùë∫ùëásubscriptùë•ùëñ\bm{S}^{T}x_{i}bold_italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT properties of the distribution. The setup is: N=2400ùëÅ2400N=2400italic_N = 2400, œÉ=1ùúé1\sigma=1italic_œÉ = 1, and d=ùëëabsentd=italic_d =930, 990, 1050, 1086, 1110, 1134, 1152, 1158, 1164, 1170, 1173, 1176, 1179, 1182, 1185, 1188, 1191, averaged over 15000 different random realizations. This was run in a cluster of servers with 250 Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2690 v4 @ 2.60GHz cores with about  9GB RAM per core, which took a few hours to run. The minimization was done using ADAM (any optimizer will work in the inseparable regime).

(2) Calculation of the margin: The setup is: N=2400ùëÅ2400N=2400italic_N = 2400, œÉ=1ùúé1\sigma=1italic_œÉ = 1, and d=ùëëabsentd=italic_d =1230, 1260, 1290, 1320, 1350, 1380, 1410, 1440, 1470, 1500, 1530, 1560, averaged over 1000 realizations. Performed on the same cluster, this took only a few hours to run.

(3) The results of the right-middel and right-bottom panels of Fig. 1. The setup is: N=400ùëÅ400N=400italic_N = 400, and d=ùëëabsentd=italic_d =20, 40, 80, 100, 120, 140, 160, 168, 180, 188, 192, 196, 200, 208, 220, 228, 240, 260, 280, 300, 320, 360, averaged over 100 realizations. This also took only a few hours to run.
